docs.title: Release notes
docs.text: About

docs.title: Network Requirements Overview
docs.text:
This documentation section provides comprehensive network requirements for deploying the ROOMNET Apple TV Solution across your infrastructure. Understanding and meeting these requirements is essential for delivering a high-quality and reliable service. Each deployment scenario includes detailed requirements and architectural best practices. Select the configuration that matches the scenario that is being installed. If you are not sure, your Project Manager will be able to advise.

The ROOMNET AppleTV solution will require more internal and external bandwidth that a traditional Hotel IPTV system, this is due to the breadth of apps and functionality available to guests that is not possible with traditional solutions. If the property has a currently working TV system, it is not a guaranteed indicator

docs.title: Deployment Scenarios
docs.text:
We've organized our network requirements into distinct deployment scenarios, each addressing specific use cases and infrastructure considerations:

Wired Network with the ROOMNET Live TV Application (Multicast)

For installations with a live TV service provided via multicast. Typically includes an on-premises IPTV headend, provided by ROOMNET or your telecoms provider.

Wired Network without Live TV (Unicast Only)

Deployments that do not have a multicast live TV service.

WiFi-Based Deployment

Specialist installations that do not have live TV. Apple TVs are on WiFi.

docs.title: ROOMNET Apple TV Network Requirements: For Networks without Multicast TV
docs.text: The ROOMNET Apple TV solution is cloud-based and enables users to stream their favorite content. A robust and correctly configured network is essential for a good user experience.

docs.title: Core Network Foundation
docs.text: This section covers the fundamental network infrastructure, including dedicated networks, IP addressing, and hardware specifications.

docs.title: Dedicated Network Infrastructure
docs.text:
Dedicated VLAN: The IPTV network must operate on a dedicated VLAN that spans the entire property as one unified network. This VLAN should NOT be the default VLAN (typically VLAN 1). If additional services beyond TV systems are required on the IPTV VLAN, inform your project manager to ensure no impact on the TV solution.

Public IP Addresses: - A dedicated static public IP address per property is required for the TV solution. - The dynamic top-shelf configuration relies on the public IP address of each Apple TV for communication with ROOMNET's cloud infrastructure. - Each property must use a unique public IP. - A maximum of two separate public IP blocks per location is supported. - If more than one public IP is used, notify your project manager or ROOMNET as soon as possible for the necessary additional DHCP configuration.

Hardware: - We recommend enterprise-grade networking hardware throughout the IPTV/Apple TV network. This includes manufacturers such as Cisco, Ruckus, and HP/Aruba. - All copper edge ports Apple TVs must be Gigabit throughout the network. - All uplink ports between switching hardware should Gigabit or better.

docs.title: Network Connectivity & Traffic Management
docs.text:
Wired Connectivity: Ensure wired Gigabit network connectivity for all in-room hardware.

Outbound Traffic: The IPTV VLAN must have no outbound restrictions. This network should be managed similarly to guest HSIA networks, meaning no filtering, proxies, packet inspection, or other technologies that could interfere with outbound network traffic. There are no requirements for inbound configurations.

docs.title: Essential Services & Servers
docs.text: This section details the critical services and servers required for the Apple TV solution to function correctly.

docs.title: ROOMNET Caching Server
docs.text:
Purpose: This server is a Mac Mini that utilizes Apple's caching service along with custom ROOMNET configurations. It hosts apps, firmware, and local replicas of assets such as branding, channel icons, and top-shelf content. It also provides a convenient way to investigate network issues.

Location & Access: The caching server must be accessible by all Apple TVs with bi-directional communication and should exist within the same VLAN as the Apple TVs.

IP Addressing: The caching server requires two static IP addresses.

docs.title: DNS Configuration
docs.text:
Primary DNS: The ROOMNET caching server will run as a virtual machine and act as the primary DNS server for the IPTV network. This allows local hosting of content like artwork and icons, improving the guest experience.

Additional DNS: ROOMNET will provide secondary and tertiary DNS servers during the project phase. It is crucial NOT to add additional DNS servers, as this will negatively affect platform performance.

docs.title: DHCP Management
docs.text:
Requirement: DHCP should be configured on the IPTV VLAN.

IP Assignment: Manual IP addresses for IPTV endpoints cannot be used because devices are wiped after checkout. However, it is acceptable to use DHCP reservations via MAC address. A complete list of MAC addresses cannot be made available until all Apple TVs have been enrolled in MDM.

docs.title: Switch & Port Optimizations
docs.text: This section outlines specific switch and port configurations needed for optimal performance and management of Apple TV traffic.

docs.title: Port-Fast Configuration
docs.text:
Requirement: All switch ports with Apple TVs connected should have port-fast enabled.

Caution: Not enabling port-fast may result in Apple TVs failing to configure automatically after a checkout.

Note: If spanning tree is not configured, this step is unnecessary.

docs.title: mDNS Traffic Management
docs.text:
Issue: Apple devices generate significant background traffic via mDNS. When many Apple TVs are on a single VLAN, this will slow content loading and hardware performance.

Solution (ACLs): To avoid these issues, apply ACLs (Access Control Lists) to block IPv4 and IPv6 mDNS traffic.

  • Example IPv4 ACL: Deny host 224.0.0.251 port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.
  • Example IPv6 ACL: Deny ff02::fb/128 any port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.

Application: Apply these restrictions to the edge ports where Apple TVs connect. If that is not possible, apply them to uplink ports to contain mDNS traffic to each switch.

Caution: Avoid general port isolation commands, as they can disrupt MDM connections and other functions.

docs.title: Bandwidth & Performance
docs.text: This section provides recommendations for managing network bandwidth to ensure a consistent and high-quality guest experience.

docs.title: Bandwidth Recommendations
docs.text:
Efficiency: Apple TVs are generally efficient in WAN bandwidth usage. Most applications do not require constant streaming from external sources, and video content (except live TV) is typically downloaded in chunks using protocols like DASH or HLS.

Recommendation: We recommend 5 Mbps per device to ensure a consistently good experience for all guests.

Management: Avoid per-device bandwidth restrictions, as they complicate management and updates. If there are concerns over bandwidth availability or management, discuss these with your account or project manager.

docs.title: Spectrum Requirements
docs.text:
For the Spectrum network components an additional Public IP is required. There will also need to be routing in place to allow communication between the Spectrum hardware and the Apple TVs

Further details of these requirements will be provided by the Spectrum team.

docs.title: Roomnet Install Guide
docs.text: This has everything you need to get up and Running

docs.title: Network Requirements
docs.text:
Understanding and meeting network requirements is essential for delivering a high-quality and reliable service. Each deployment scenario includes requirements and architectural best practices. Select the configuration that matches the scenario that is being installed. If you are not sure, your project manager will be able to advise.

The ROOMNET AppleTV solution will require more internal and external bandwidth that a traditional Hotel IPTV system, this is due to the breadth of apps and functionality available to guests that is not possible with traditional solutions. AppleTVs also prefer a Gigabit network connection, most TV Hardware maxes out at 100MB. This can hi-light old or damaged wiring that is not upto maintaining a gigabit link.

docs.title: Deployment Scenarios
docs.text:
We've organized our network requirements into distinct deployment scenarios, each addressing specific use cases and infrastructure considerations:

  • Network Without Multicast There is either no Live TV or the Live TV is provided over the Internet.
  • Network With Multicast The ROOMNET Live TV will be used, TV channels are provided via local multicast streams
  • AppleTVs on Wifi A specialist setup for poperties that have no wired option in the guest room.

docs.title: Configuration & Install
docs.text:
• Golden Room
  • TV Setup
  • Remote Control
  • Onboarding Devices

docs.title: Apple MDM Setup
docs.text:
All Apple TVs must be enrolled to an Apple Business manager account. This must be done at point of purchase. If ROOMNET are providing your Apple TV hardware, this section is not relevant. And you can skip to install location.

If You are procuring your Apple TVs they will need to be enrolled to an Apple Business manager account, this must be done at point of purchase. There are two scenarios

docs.title: Using your own Business Manager account
docs.text: If you have an Apple Business Manager account and wish to assign your AppleTVs to it, we will need to link your business manager account to our MDM. Your project manager will discuss the process with you. You can purchase the AppleTVs before the MDM link is complete.

docs.title: Using the ROOMNET Business manager account
docs.text:
If you are procuring the Apple TVs but do not have or wish to use your own business manager account, the AppleTVs can be assigned to ROOMNETs account. Your project manager will provide you with our account ID. We will require the account ID of the reseller you are purchasing from so they can be allowed to assign devices to us. When purchasing ensure the reseller is informed you want to add the AppleTVs to a business manager account and they have our account ID.

Warning

If this is not completed at point of purchase it will delay the install.

docs.title: ROOMNET Apple TV Network Requirements: For Networks with Multicast TV
docs.text: This document details the general requirements of the ROOMNET Apple TV Solution and covers additional requirements for providing multicast IPTV streams. The Guide assumes the IPTV streamer and the Apple TVs will exist within a single common VLAN. Any differing configuration is beyond the scope of this document and should be raised with your project manager allowing us to discuss and advise accordingly.

docs.title: Core Network Foundation
docs.text: This section covers the fundamental network infrastructure, including dedicated networks, IP addressing, and hardware specifications.

docs.title: Dedicated Network Infrastructure
docs.text:
Dedicated VLAN: The IPTV network must operate on a dedicated VLAN that spans the entire property as one unified network. This VLAN should NOT be the default VLAN (typically VLAN 1). If additional devices beyond the IPTV streamer and ROOMNET provided equipment are to be included in the VLAN, inform your project manager so we can evaluate any impact to the solution.

Public IP Addresses: - A dedicated static public IP address per property is required for the TV solution. Multiple Static IPs can be accommodated but may require additional network configuration. - The dynamic top-shelf configuration relies on the public IP address of each Apple TV for communication with ROOMNET's cloud infrastructure. To ensure the correct branding is shown on screen, each property needs to use unique public IPs - If static public IPs are not available this will reduce branding opportunities within the solution.

Hardware: - We recommend enterprise-grade networking hardware throughout the IPTV/Apple TV network. This includes manufacturers such as Cisco, Ruckus, and HP/Aruba. - All copper edge ports Apple TVs must be Gigabit throughout the network. - All uplink ports between switching hardware should Gigabit or better. Preferably 10GB or better.

docs.title: Network Connectivity & Traffic Management
docs.text:
Wired Connectivity: Ensure wired Gigabit network connectivity for all in-room hardware.

Outbound Traffic: The IPTV VLAN must have no outbound restrictions. This network should be managed similarly to guest HSIA networks, meaning no filtering, proxies, packet inspection, or other technologies that could interfere with outbound network traffic. There are no requirements for inbound configurations.

docs.title: Essential Services & Servers
docs.text: This section details the critical services and servers required for the Apple TV solution to function correctly.

docs.title: ROOMNET Caching Server
docs.text:
Purpose: This server is a Mac Mini that utilizes Apple's caching service along with custom ROOMNET configurations. It hosts apps, firmware, and local replicas of assets such as branding, channel icons, and top-shelf content. It also provides a convenient way to investigate network issues.

Location & Access: The caching server must be accessible by all Apple TVs with bi-directional communication and should exist within the same VLAN as the Apple TVs.

IP Addressing: The caching server requires two static IP addresses.

docs.title: DNS Configuration
docs.text:
Primary DNS: The ROOMNET caching server will run as a virtual machine and act as the primary DNS server for the IPTV network. This allows local hosting of content like artwork and icons, improving the guest experience.

Additional DNS: ROOMNET will provide secondary and tertiary DNS servers during the project phase. It is crucial NOT to add additional DNS servers, as this will negatively affect platform performance.

docs.text:
Requirement: DHCP should be configured on the IPTV VLAN.

IP Assignment: Manual IP addresses for IPTV endpoints cannot be used because devices are wiped after checkout. However, it is acceptable to use DHCP reservations via MAC address. A complete list of MAC addresses cannot be made available until all Apple TVs have been enrolled in MDM.

docs.title: Switch & Port Optimizations
docs.text: This section outlines specific switch and port configurations needed for optimal performance and management of Apple TV traffic.

docs.title: Port-Fast Configuration
docs.text:
Requirement: All switch ports with Apple TVs connected should have port-fast enabled.

Caution: Not enabling port-fast may result in Apple TVs failing to configure automatically after a checkout.

Note: If spanning tree is not configured, this step is unnecessary.

docs.title: mDNS Traffic Management
docs.text:
Issue: Apple devices generate significant background traffic via mDNS. When many Apple TVs are on a single VLAN, this will slow content loading and hardware performance.

Solution (ACLs): To avoid these issues, apply ACLs (Access Control Lists) to block IPv4 and IPv6 mDNS traffic.

  • Example IPv4 ACL: Deny host 224.0.0.251 port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.
  • Example IPv6 ACL: Deny ff02::fb/128 any port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.

Application: Apply these restrictions to the edge ports where Apple TVs connect. If that is not possible, apply them to uplink ports to contain mDNS traffic to each switch.

Caution: Avoid general port isolation commands, as they can disrupt MDM connections and other functions.

docs.title: Bandwidth & Performance
docs.text: This section provides recommendations for managing network bandwidth to ensure a consistent and high-quality guest experience.

docs.title: Bandwidth Recommendations
docs.text:
Efficiency: Apple TVs are generally efficient in WAN bandwidth usage. Most applications do not require constant streaming from external sources, and video content (except live TV) is typically downloaded in chunks using protocols like DASH or HLS.

Recommendation: We recommend 5 Mbps per device to ensure a consistently good experience for all guests.

Management: Avoid per-device bandwidth restrictions, as they complicate management and updates. If there are concerns over bandwidth availability or management, discuss these with your account or project manager.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: This guide covers onboarding Apple Business Manager enrolled Apple TVs to ROOMNETs Apple TV platform.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Info

You will not be able to start the onboarding process until the basic configuration of your property has been completed by a ROOMNET engineer. Your project manager will confirm when this has been completed.

  • All Apple TVs must be enrolled to Apple Business Manager and associated with ROOMNET's MDM platform.
  • Physical access to the Apple TVs that require setup.
  • Apple TV must have Internet access.
  • A device with Internet access and Chrome browser (i.e., Laptop/Smartphone).
  • Access to GLYDE and the ability to add devices to the correct property.
  • A working remote control. Ideally the ROOMENT remote so it can be configured and tested at the same time.

docs.title: Onboarding
docs.text:
1. Log in to GLYDE, navigate to the correct property (if multiple are available to you) and select Activate from the navigation bar.
  2. Power on the Apple TV.
  3. The Apple TV will boot to a screen asking you to interact with the remote control. DO NOT do anything. After a delay of up to 30 seconds, the Apple TV will automatically configure itself.
  4. Once configured, the Apple TV will go to its main menu and the onboarding app will install and launch. If you are stuck on a grey screen, press the back button on the remote several times to show the onboarding app.
  5. Enter the code presented on screen into the Activate section of GLYDE and select the room number the Apple TV is being installed in.
  6. Click Register.
  7. On successful registration, you will be taken to the device page. Expand the settings section and set the device name to match the room and location:
  8. On successful registration, the Apple TV will reset and go through the auto-configuration process again. When it reaches the main menu, it will install required applications and be ready to use.

Info

When Naming the devices consider how many are installed in each room. If there are multiple name them so they are easily identifiable e.g. Room 101 Bedroom, Room 101 Lounge etc...

This will make it easier for guest who want to airplay content and aid device identification in glyde.

docs.title: Apple TV Does Not Automatically Configure
docs.text:
1. Make sure you have waited long enough. If text appears at the bottom of the screen with instructions to pair the remote, there is a problem.
  2. Check the network is correctly configured and the port in use is live.
  3. Check the Apple TV has been correctly assigned to MDM.
  4. Escalate to your ROOMNET project manager.

docs.title: Device Enrollment Application Not Installed/Launching
docs.text:
1. Ensure the device has Internet connectivity. Go to the App store and check if it shows content.
  2. Press the Back/Exit key on the remote control several times.
  3. Attempt to reset the device (factory reset/device wipe).
  4. If the issue remains, please report it to ROOMNET support.

docs.title: Error: "UDID is Already Registered"
docs.text:
1. Ensure Internet connectivity.
  2. Power cycle the device.
  3. If the issue remains, please report it to ROOMNET support.

docs.title: Error on Onboarding Device: "Something Went Wrong"
docs.text:
1. Power cycle the device.
  2. Attempt to re-register.
  3. If the issue remains, please report it to ROOMNET support.

docs.title: Apple TV Does Not Reset After a Successful Registration
docs.text:
1. Power cycle the device.
  2. Attempt to re-register.
  3. If the issue remains, please report it to ROOMNET support.

docs.title: TV/ATV Remote Compatibility Matrix
docs.text:
Search for the Full TV model Number in the Table below. Note the Type, Status Details and Remote Mode.

Info

If the screen type is not listed as hospitality there may be some caveats, such as not being able to clone configurations or use settings that appear in hospitality models. Your project manager will discuss this with you.

Status - If listed as Incompatible, the TV will need to be replaced as there are fundamental issues in compatibility with our solution.

Notes - Contains any details that need consideration.

Remote Mode - CEC means the Apple TV can be hidden anywhere, IR means a line of sight between it and the remote control is needed.

docs.title: TV Hardware Compatibility
docs.text: The ROOMNET Apple TV solution works with a wide range of TVs. But not all TV support the same technologies and functions. To help us understand the capabilities of the TVs that are going to be used we need to run a few tests against them.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Hospitality specific TVs manufactured from 2016 are the best option as they have functionality and settings specific to the needs of guest rooms. Retail TVs from LG, and Sony manufactured from 2018 typically work well Samsung TVs that are not hospitality models (This includes their Professional TVs) manufactured after 2022 feature a device discovery service that cannot be disabled and can cause issues and are generally not recommended.

docs.title: Functionality
docs.text:
The important functions are - Can the TV be configured to always power on to the Apple TV? - Are we able to hide any pop ups or overlays that may appear. - Can we control the TV and Apple TV using CEC Which allows the Apple TV to be placed anywhere or hidden completely. - If CEC does not work does the remote control everything using Infra Red? - Are there any obvious issues with the TV that would cause issues for guests?

Info

If CEC is not a reliable option, the Apple TV will need to placed in a location where the remote control can send it commands. This will need to be considered as part of the room design.

docs.title: Steps to verify TV compatibility
docs.text:
1. Check the TV model number against our list of tested TVs.
  2. If the TV does not appear on our test list, it will need to be tested. Your project manager will arrange this with you.

docs.title: Outcomes
docs.text: Ideally all TV models are supported

docs.title: TV Configuration
docs.text: Each TV need to be correctly configured. The essential configuration requirements are: - TV powers on to HDMI1 - Any overlays or home menus are disabled (where possible) -

docs.title: ROOMNET Apple TV Network Requirements: For Networks without Live TV
docs.text:
The ROOMNET Apple TV solution is cloud-based and enables users to stream their favorite content.

Understanding and meeting network requirements is essential for delivering a high-quality and reliable service. Each deployment scenario includes requirements and architectural best practices. Select the configuration that matches the scenario that is being installed. If you are not sure, your project manager will be able to advise.

The ROOMNET AppleTV solution will require more internal and external bandwidth that a traditional Hotel IPTV system, this is due to the breadth of apps and functionality available to guests that is not possible with traditional solutions.

docs.title: Core Network Foundation
docs.text: This section covers the fundamental network infrastructure, including dedicated networks, IP addressing, and hardware specifications.

docs.title: Dedicated Network Infrastructure
docs.text:
Dedicated VLAN: The IPTV network must operate on a dedicated VLAN that spans the entire property as one unified network. This VLAN should NOT be the default VLAN (typically VLAN 1). If additional services beyond TV systems are required on the IPTV VLAN, inform your project manager to ensure no impact on the TV solution.

Public IP Addresses: - A dedicated static public IP address per property is required for the TV solution. - The dynamic top-shelf configuration relies on the public IP address of each Apple TV for communication with ROOMNET's cloud infrastructure. - Each property must use a unique public IP. - A maximum of two separate public IP blocks per location is supported. - If more than one public IP is used, notify your project manager or ROOMNET as soon as possible for the necessary additional DHCP configuration.

Hardware: - We recommend enterprise-grade networking hardware throughout the IPTV/Apple TV network. This includes manufacturers such as Cisco, Ruckus, and HP/Aruba. - All copper edge ports Apple TVs must be Gigabit throughout the network. - All uplink ports between switching hardware should Gigabit or better.

docs.title: Network Connectivity & Traffic Management
docs.text:
Wired Connectivity: Ensure wired Gigabit network connectivity for all in-room hardware.

Outbound Traffic: The IPTV VLAN must have no outbound restrictions. This network should be managed similarly to guest HSIA networks, meaning no filtering, proxies, packet inspection, or other technologies that could interfere with outbound network traffic. There are no requirements for inbound configurations.

docs.title: Essential Services & Servers
docs.text: This section details the critical services and servers required for the Apple TV solution to function correctly.

docs.title: ROOMNET Caching Server
docs.text:
Purpose: This server is a Mac Mini that utilizes Apple's caching service along with custom ROOMNET configurations. It hosts apps, firmware, and local replicas of assets such as branding, channel icons, and top-shelf content. It also provides a convenient way to investigate network issues.

Location & Access: The caching server must be accessible by all Apple TVs with bi-directional communication and should exist within the same VLAN as the Apple TVs.

IP Addressing: The caching server requires two static IP addresses.

docs.title: DNS Configuration
docs.text:
Primary DNS: The ROOMNET caching server will run as a virtual machine and act as the primary DNS server for the IPTV network. This allows local hosting of content like artwork and icons, improving the guest experience.

Additional DNS: ROOMNET will provide secondary and tertiary DNS servers during the project phase. It is crucial NOT to add additional DNS servers, as this will negatively affect platform performance.

docs.title: DHCP Management
docs.text:
Requirement: DHCP should be configured on the IPTV VLAN.

IP Assignment: Manual IP addresses for IPTV endpoints cannot be used because devices are wiped after checkout. However, it is acceptable to use DHCP reservations via MAC address. A complete list of MAC addresses cannot be made available until all Apple TVs have been enrolled in MDM.

docs.title: Switch & Port Optimizations
docs.text: This section outlines specific switch and port configurations needed for optimal performance and management of Apple TV traffic.

docs.title: Port-Fast Configuration
docs.text:
Requirement: All switch ports with Apple TVs connected should have port-fast enabled.

Caution: Not enabling port-fast may result in Apple TVs failing to configure automatically after a checkout.

Note: If spanning tree is not configured, this step is unnecessary.

docs.title: mDNS Traffic Management
docs.text:
Issue: Apple devices generate significant background traffic via mDNS. When many Apple TVs are on a single VLAN, this will slow content loading and hardware performance.

Solution (ACLs): To avoid these issues, apply ACLs (Access Control Lists) to block IPv4 and IPv6 mDNS traffic.

  • Example IPv4 ACL: Deny host 224.0.0.251 port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.
  • Example IPv6 ACL: Deny ff02::fb/128 any port 5353 and permit all other UDP traffic.

Application: Apply these restrictions to the edge ports where Apple TVs connect. If that is not possible, apply them to uplink ports to contain mDNS traffic to each switch.

Caution: Avoid general port isolation commands, as they can disrupt MDM connections and other functions.

docs.title: Bandwidth & Performance
docs.text: This section provides recommendations for managing network bandwidth to ensure a consistent and high-quality guest experience.

docs.title: Bandwidth Recommendations
docs.text:
Efficiency: Apple TVs are generally efficient in WAN bandwidth usage. Most applications do not require constant streaming from external sources, and video content (except live TV) is typically downloaded in chunks using protocols like DASH or HLS.

Recommendation: We recommend 5 Mbps per device to ensure a consistently good experience for all guests.

Management: Avoid per-device bandwidth restrictions, as they complicate management and updates. If there are concerns over bandwidth availability or management, discuss these with your account or project manager.

docs.title: Support Escalation & Fault Reporting
docs.text: ROOMNET offers the following options for all support issues, incident reporting, scheduled repair and maintenance requests, general queries, and change requests.

docs.title: ROOMNET Ticket Service
docs.text:
If your query or incident report is affecting multiple stations, rooms, or guests and your service is moderately impacted, please raise a ticket via the Roomnet Support Portal

Please follow the guidelines below to ensure your ticket is associated with the correct priority level.

If you do not have a login for the ROOMNET Support Portal or are unable to create one, you can raise a ticket by emailing support@roomnet.com. Once your ticket is created, you will receive an invite to create an account on our ticketing portal.

docs.title: Priority Levels
docs.text:
Priority Level Description Response Time MEDIUM / Priority 3 Network or service is moderately impacted but most business remains functional. Your ticket will be reviewed and responded to within 12 hours. Remedial action will be completed or planned within 48 hours. HIGH / Priority 2 Network or service is impacted but not down. Business impact may be high. Workaround may be available. Your ticket will be reviewed and responded to within 4 hours. Remedial action will be completed or planned within 24 hours. CRITICAL / Priority 1 Network service is completely down and business is impacted dramatically. No known workaround. Your ticket will be reviewed and responded to within 1 hour. Remedial action will be completed or planned within 4 hours. This service is exclusively for Priority 1 issues. Please see notes on misuse at the end of this document.

Info

The above response guidelines are considered as a maximum threshold only. We will endeavor to respond to all matters as quickly as possible.

docs.title: Emergency Service Line
docs.text:
If your query or incident report is deemed Priority 1 and is affecting a large majority of your properties, stations, rooms, or guests, please contact the 3rd line support team directly via:

  • USA: +1 (800) 480-7974
  • UK: +44 (0)207 692 6634
  • AUS: +61 (2) 9159 8001

Warning

These numbers have been provided exclusively to expedite Priority 1 issues only. As such, the continued misreporting of issues via the emergency number may incur additional fees. Your account manager will discuss this with you before any charges are levied.

docs.title: Roomnet Install Guide
docs.text: This has everything you need to get up and Running

docs.title: Network Requirements
docs.text:
Understanding and meeting network requirements is essential for delivering a high-quality and reliable service. Each deployment scenario includes requirements and architectural best practices. Select the configuration that matches the scenario that is being installed. If you are not sure, your project manager will be able to advise.

The ROOMNET AppleTV solution will require more internal and external bandwidth that a traditional Hotel IPTV system, this is due to the breadth of apps and functionality available to guests that is not possible with traditional solutions. AppleTVs also prefer a Gigabit network connection, most TV Hardware maxes out at 100MB. This can hi-light old or damaged wiring that is not upto maintaining a gigabit link.

docs.title: Deployment Scenarios
docs.text:
We've organized our network requirements into distinct deployment scenarios, each addressing specific use cases and infrastructure considerations:

  • Network Without Multicast There is either no Live TV or the Live TV is provided over the Internet.
  • Network With Multicast The ROOMNET Live TV will be used, TV channels are provided via local multicast streams
  • AppleTVs on Wifi A specialist setup for poperties that have no wired option in the guest room.

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• AppleTV
  • TV Hardware
  • TV Compatibility

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Glyde is the web management interface for The ROOMNET Apple TV solution. The interface provides configuration and management options for Apple TVs, areas and the balcony App. It also provides metrics for TV channel usage for properties using the ROOMNET TV Application.

docs.title: Access
docs.text: Access Glyde at glyde.roomnet.com A login is required and can be requested via your project manager or support. On first login you will be prompted to setup multi-factor-authentication

docs.title: Site Selector
docs.text: If your login has access to multiple properties you will be presented with the site selector. Choose the required property. The site selector can be accessed again by clicking the icon at the top of the page.

docs.title: Settings/Time Zone
docs.text: Clicking the icon in the top right will allow you to change how times are shown throughout the glyde interface. The default behaviour will use the timezone of the device you are using. Selecting Use Site's Timezone will change this behaviour to show any date and time based on the time zone of the property. This can be helpful when working across multiple properties especially if they are not in your location.

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text: On Login the dashboard is displayed. Overview data is displayed for devices, areas, effusion server and PMS events.

docs.title: Devices
docs.text:
Reported status of devices is shown here.

  • Total - All devices registered to this Property.
  • Alerts - Number of devices that are not communicating with Glyde.
  • Active - Number of actively communicating devices.
  • Spare - Number of devices marked as spare.
  • Quarantined - Number of devices marked with this status. This is typically used for devices that are under investigation.
  • Missing - Number of devices marked as missing. Typically used for devices that cannot be located.
  • Without Areas - Devices that have not been assigned to an area. If there are any devices without area this should be resolved quickly.

docs.title: Alert Metrics
docs.text: Provides a 30 day history of device alerts. Can be helpful in monitoring the overall reliability of network connectivity and troubleshooting.

docs.title: Areas
docs.text:
Total areas configured and any that do not have devices assigned to them.

Info

An Area is a container for devices. This is commonly a guest room, but could something like a gym or a public space.

docs.title: Effusion metrics
docs.text: Reports the status of the MacMini(s) installed in the network. These MacMinis provide a local copy of assets and applications, ensuring the guest experience is as smooth as possible. In normal operation each section should display a green tick.

docs.title: PMS
docs.text: The PMS interface is important in making sure all guest data is removed at the end of their stay. If there is any outage or odd behaviour devices may be reset too often or not at all. The line graph can be interacted with showing the number of events over the last 30 days. The section on the right gives a snapshot of the last events received and the times they occurred.

docs.title: Devices
docs.text:
All devices assigned to the property can be viewed and managed from this section. An overview of all devices is provided. Any devices with an Orange warning triangle are not communicating with Glyde and require attention.

Clicking on any of the cetegories along the top of the page will flitler the device list.

Clicking on a device will reveal the details page

This section provides detailed information and status details for a single device. There are also aspects of the device that can be configured.

  • Cleardown - This will perform a complete wipe and rebuild of the device. All guest data will be removed including logins.
  • Reset - A simple restart of the device.
  • Delete - This will completely delete the device from glyde and your property. This is only available to site admins and should only be used under guidance from a ROOMNET team member.

docs.title: Device Settings
docs.text: • Device Name - Sets the name of the device. This is the name displayed in the system and the name guests will see if they want to use Airplay. Typically this would be the room number. In cases whjere there are multiple devices in a room, please name the deive so it can be identified clearly, for example Room 101 Bedroom

docs.title: Associated Areas
docs.text: Allows association of devices and areas. A devcie can be part of multiple areas, they may be useful if a room can be sold in different configurations. It is important this is set accuratley as PMS events are area based so setting the wrong value here will result in the AppleTV not resetting on checkout or restting when a different room checks out.

docs.title: History
docs.text: Helpful for Troubleshooting, displays the most recent events that have been sent to this device.

docs.title: Areas
docs.text:
Areas are used to group devices. Whilst typically a guest room, an area can be any logical grouoing of one or more devices. This could be a public space, meeting room, gym etc...

  • Name is a recognisable value for each Area that can be set to any area required.
  • Identifier is used to match the events your PMS sends us to areas. This must match the room values in the PMS.

Clicking on an area will take you to its details page.

  • Cleardown: This will perform a complete wipe and rebuild of all devcies assigned to this area.
  • Restart: Triggers a restart of all devcies assigned to the room.
  • Delete: This will completely delete the area from glyde and your property. This is only available to site admins and should only be used under guidance from a ROOMNET team member. This does not remove any devices associated to the area, but they will no longer respon to check out events for th area that has been removed and will need to be assigned to a new area.

docs.title: Area Settings
docs.text: Identifier and name can be changed here. Notes can be added as required.

docs.title: Associated Devices
docs.text: Allows assignment of any enrolled device to teh selected area. Multiple devcies can be assigned to each area.

docs.title: Activate
docs.text: Used as part of the device onboarding process

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: This section is only editable by ROOMNET staff and for reference only.

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text: Recurring tasks are defined in this section, As with Settings This section is only editable by ROOMNET staff.

docs.title: TV APP
docs.text: The ROOMNET TV application provides live TV streams, typically using local Terrestrial and/or satellite feeds. This guide is only relevant to the ROOMNET Live TV app.

docs.title: TV Metrics
docs.text:
Metrics data is only available when the ROOMNET TV application is used. Metrics are collected anonymously and displayed as an overall for the property. The data displayed covers the last 30 days.

The data provided can be used to establish when TV channels are being watched and if there are any channels that are not being used. Channels that are not being used could be removed / replaced, making better usage of your hardware or subscriptions.

Overall viewing time is displayed at the top of the page. The green line shows collective hours viewed per day, the yellow an average viewing time based on the last 30 days.

Below the overall graph, several view are provided showing most and least used channels, usage by day and usage by hour of the day.

Each graph has a full report button. Clicking this will display a full list of channels available at the property and collective hours viewed over the last 30 days.

docs.title: Balcony App
docs.text: The Balcony section provides configuration for the Balcony App. This is covered in the balcony section

docs.title: Remote Control
docs.text:
The ROOMNET remote control is built to work with the Apple TV in-room solution. The design is simple, containing only the required buttons and nothing more. The Remote supports hundreds of TV brands but works best when controlling Hospitality specific TVs. In most scenarios the remote will communicate directly with the TV emulating the behaviour of the TVs factory remote. In the recommended configuration, navigation commands are sent via the TV to the Apple TV allowing the Apple TV to be hidden or placed as required. This is achieved using a feature built into most TVs called CEC.

There may be scenarios where this function does not work correctly or is not supported by your TV. In this case the remote can talk to the Apple TV directly, but this requires a line of sight between the remote and the Apple TV to work reliably.

docs.title: Setting up the remote
docs.text: Information on programming the remote control is available in the remote control setup guide

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Although we erase all guest data on checkout, some guests may be more security concious and waht to make sure their data is gone before they leave the room. This is exactly why we created the Reset app. Witha. few clicsk the Guest can begin the reset process and once complete, confiorm their logins and data have gone.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: There are no user configurable componenets in the rest app.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: As there are not configurable componenets any issues with the reset application should be reported to Support
